advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT, APRIL 1987</strong></font><br><blockquote>From Personal Computer World magazine.<br> Advert said:<br><font color="#666666"> It's an extraordinarily powerful machine which offers word-processing, spreadsheet, and a set of time and data-management tools in a single, highly porlable package.<br> At £199.95. the Z88 is supplied with 32K resident RAM. Extra 32K costs under £20, extra 128K under £50!<br> And heavy users Will be able to expand the RAM to an astonishing 3 Mbytes, using plug-in RAM cartridges.<br> For printing text or data, the Z88 connects direcly to most popular RS232 compatible printers, while for permanent storage the Z88 employs removable solid state EPROM cartridges - no tape to break, no delicate disc to damage.<br> Though the Z88 is a powerful, full facility, self-contained computer, it also acts as an extension of an office micro, connecting directly to allow exchange of text or data.<br> For every personal computer user, the Z88 offers a comprehensive specification in a package of unparalleled portability.</font> </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> LEAFLET #1</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> COMMODORE BROCHURE</strong></font><br><blockquote>Photo taken from an Amiga 3000 brochure.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>''It's time''<br> ''ATMOS from Oric : the definitive computer''</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>>  GERMAN LEAFLET #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>Preliminary/New product leaflet. For exhibitions only<br><br><br> "The new Personal Computer from SHARP - particularly developed for personal use."<br><br> Note the optional Quick Disc drive.<p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>www.sharpmz.org</b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> NEO-GEO ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://spoonman.roarvgm.com/neogeo/" target="_blank">SpoonMan's Neo-Geo page</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.guiguy.com/Schiff/" target="_blank">www.guiguy.com/Schiff/</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote>New version with Shugart 360 KB formatted capacity floppy drives. Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">North Star has quadrupled the disk capacity of the Horizon computer but prices have increased a modest 15 percent. On a dollar per byte basis, that's a bargain that is hard to beat!...</font><br><br> 1979 prices for assembled versions including 32KB RAM, one parallel and two serial I/O ports:<br> 1 F.D. version: <b>$2565</b><br> 2 F.D. version: <b>$3215</b> </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> POPULAR ELECTRONICS</strong></font><br><blockquote>Cover and extracts of a 6 page article in the January 1975 issue of Popular Electronics</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT.</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT #3</strong></font><br><blockquote>''Atmos from Oric : the definitive computer''<br> ''Now, go !''</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT#2</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is another french advert, not from CBS, but from an independant store "le jeu electronique". <br><br> Only the expansion module #3 was available in France and people had to buy a Colecovision if they wanted to have an Adam !</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH FLYER</strong></font><br><blockquote>... featuring the Intellivoice</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT #4</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://osaki.cool.ne.jp/hc/computer/canon/canon.html#x07">Handheld computer & Pocket calculator Museum</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT (FEB. 1980) </strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to David Wilson for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD</strong></font><br><blockquote>"From 1 to 16 users"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. AD. (1983) #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>First advert - January 1983</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PRICE LIST</strong></font><br><blockquote>April 1987 price list, including VAT.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> BROCHURE #5</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. AD (MAR. 86)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said<br><br><font color="#666666"> The electric typewriter's days are numbered. Because now there's a machine that put real wordprocessing power within everyone's reach.<br> The Amstrad PCW 8256 is a complete word-processor and a powerful computer in one unit.<br> And it's unbelievably low price includes a screen with built-in disc drive, keyboard, printer and word processing software...</font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT (1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.pugly.juice.or.jp/pugly/oldpc/" target="_blank">Pugly's web site</a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. AD. (JUN. 83)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> We've wired CompuPro savvy into three of the industry most potent new processor chips. The result: more performance, more quality, more reliability, and higher speed for greater throughput than ever before.<br> CPU 286 and CPU 16032 can upgrade present systems to state-of-the-art operation, or serve as powerful fundations for new systems. CPU 68K, aside from being a superd CPU board, is also the core of our system 816/68K.<br> As always, CompuPro kept an eye on the future in designing these CPUs. With a CompuPro, you don't shudder a fast-changing technology, you welcome it.<br><br> We give you brains and brawn in one box, and that's beautiful. </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"the competition is dumb !"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"The TO7 from Thomson has everything needed to fill the empty cells"</blockquote>

computer.builtInGames: MS-DOS and GW-Basic delivered on disks
computer.description:
This computer was built at Meaux (France, Paris area) by Logabax which was owned by Olivetti at 65%. It was in fact the international version of the Olivetti M24.
This was a highly PC compatible system. It means that it was truely hardware and sotfware compatible with the IBM PC of the time. Back then, all "PC compatible" systems were not exactly 100% compatible... so it was a real marketing argument for the Persona 1600. There were two true tests to know if a system was really IBM PC compatible: Lotus 1-2-3 and Microsoft Flight Simulator, and the Persona 1600 was running both with no problem.
But in addition to its good compatibility, the Persona 1600 was offering more than the IBM PC itself: built-in RS232c and Centronics interface, more complete keyboard, better graphic possibilities (640 x 400) and 7 free expansion slots (instead of 3 for the IBM PC). Even the CPU (8086) was faster than the 8088 used by the IBM PC.
It was very well known in France because it was used as a server for Thomson TO7 and MO5 computer networks in schools (Nanor?seaux).
It ran under MS-DOS 2.11 or CP/M 86. It was possible to connect an optional hard disk (from 10 to 50 Mb). The Persona 1600 was sold with a 12" green monochrom, or a 14" color monitor.
computer.keyboard: Separated full-stroke keyboard, 102 keys, numeric keypad, 18 function keysA standard IBM keyboard (83 keys) was also proposed
computer.language: MS-DOS and GW-Basic delivered on disks
computer.name: PERSONA 1600
computer.peripherals: Hard-disk, IEEE 488, RS 422, RS 232, PC Net boards, IBM 3278 coaxial network board, mouse
computer.price: 1 disk-drive system :3350 (France, 84)2 disk-drives system : 3811 (France, 84)128k, monochrome, 2 x drives 720k : 6015 (France, 85)

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> 20 MB HDD VERSION</strong></font><br><blockquote>The keyboard design was slightly different from the FDD version, particularly the function keys.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> MAIN UNIT</strong></font><br><blockquote>On the HDD version a red plastic mask allowed to see the HDD leds (Power and Busy) by transparency.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> KEYBOARD CLOSE-UP</strong></font><br><blockquote>User could choose between two keyboards: an IBM PC style one, or this Olivetti keyboard specially developed for the Persona 1600.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> BACK SIDE</strong></font><br><blockquote>The black plastic box holds a large aluminium fan.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> BACK PANEL</strong></font><br><blockquote>On can spot the various connectors:<br> • Power sockets and switchs<br> • Keyboard (not compatible with standard PC keyboards)<br> • Parallel and Serial<br> • Video, located on the first expansion slot.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> INSIDE THE HDD VERSION</strong></font><br><blockquote>In this version, it isn't possible to add any expansion card. Only to cards are available, video (left) and HDD controller.<br> Stangely, the video card is used as a bridge between the mainboard located below the metal frame and the expansion slots card. Here a one-slot card is attached, it supports the HDD controller card.<br> The hard disk drive is a 20 MB model made by Olivetti.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> INSIDE THE FDD VERSION</strong></font><br><blockquote>This version features a 7-slot backplane connected to the video card. Green slots are used for specific Olivetti cards. A RAM expansion card is fitted in one of the slots.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> MAINBOARD</strong></font><br><blockquote>The components side faces the bottom of the case. <br><br> <b><font color="blue">(1)</font></b> "Bridge" video card connectors<br> <b><font color="blue">(2)</font></b> Optional HDD controller socket<br> <b><font color="blue">(3)</font></b> Western Digital FDD controller<br> <b><font color="blue">(4)</font></b> Optional 8087 math coprocessor socket<br> <b><font color="blue">(5)</font></b> 8086 microprocessor<br> <b><font color="blue">(6)</font></b> 512 KB optional chips (16 x 41256)<br> <b><font color="blue">(7)</font></b> 128 KB base RAM (16 x 4164)<br> <b><font color="blue">(8)</font></b> BIOS ROMs<br> <b><font color="blue">(9)</font></b> CMOS and clock battery, Reset switch and beeper<br> <b><font color="blue">(10)</font></b> Various NEC I/O chips<br> <b><font color="blue">(11)</font></b> Keyboard ROM<br></blockquote>
